 REPUBIUC OF CAPE VERDE CAPACITY BUILDING PROJECT FOR PRIVATE SECTOR PROMOTION L INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Government of Cape Verde has requested IDA's assistance in financing a program to implement an export-led development strategy and to create an environment conducive to private sector growth by removing obstacles to the development of private enterprises, providing support to private sector institutions, and liberalizing and expanding the financial system. This strategy is set out in the Government's Letter of Private Sector Development Policy (Annex& . The proposed project would finance: (a) a program to strengthen the institutions supporting the private sector, (b) the development of Mindelo's export-processing zone; and (c) a program to strengthen the financial system. 1.2 Total project costs are estimated at about US$12.7 million equivalent, net of taxes and duties, of which IDA would finance about US$11.4 million equivalent. The Government would contribute about US$1.3 million equivalent. IL SECTORAL CONTEXT A. BACKGROUND 2.1 Cape Verde consists of ten islands located 650 kilometers off the coast of Senegal, with a land area of about 4,036 square kilometers. Only nine of the islands are populated, with half of the resident population of about 400,000 (in 1992) living on the island of Santiago, mainly in Praia, the capital city. Only one tenth of the country's land base is arable, which implies a high population density (808 persons) per square kilometer of arable land. The Sahelian climate, with prolonged periods of drought, a marked shortage of fresh water supplies in terms of rivers and springs, and a high natural population growth rate of 2.7% combine to produce intolerable pressure on the country's fragile agricultural base. Even in good rain years, the country can only produce 10 to 15% of its total cereal requirements. The poor natural resource base, particularly with respect to fresh water, and the absence of a mineral resource base, have led to high rates of emigration, driven even higher in times of drought. As a result, twice as many Cape Verdeans live abroad as on the islands. 2.2 Development Constraints. Cape Verde's development is hindered by poor natural resources, prolonged cycles of drought, and small domestic markets. Moreover, the scattered nature of the islands results in costly conmmunications. After independence in 1975, the development of a virtualy nonexistent economy into a modern one was a formidable challenge for the government which chose to perform the role of an entrepreneur in agriculture, industry and services. Reliance on the private sector was not actively pursued. The government sought official development assistance and allocated it to the development of public enterprises in key sectors. The strategy of creating public enterprises to produce for the limited domestic market
 2 adversely affected the efficiency and competitiveness of the national economy. This option deterred both foreign and private investment for years. 2.3 Structure of the Economy. Cape Verde's economy has been traditionally based on services. The paucity of natural resources, excepting the ocean and an extensive coastline, means that services, rather than agriculture, have been the mainstay of the economy. In the 1980s, the service sector accounted for 60% of GDP and employed about 41% of the active population. Commerce, transport, and public services accounted for 47% of value added. Tourism, however, is still in too nascent a form to contribute significantly to value added, job creation and export earnings. Construction and industrial production, consisting largely of light manufacturing, fish processing and artisanal production, accounted for about 11.5 and 6.5% of the total value added respectively in the 1980s. The primary sector contributed only about 13% of GDP because of low agricultural potential and inefficient exploitation of reasonably well endowed fishery resources (3% of value added) by a public sector dominated industry. The primary sector employed about 30% of the active population, of which agriculture employed about 24%. 2.4 External Sector. Foreign trade is characterized by modest merchandise export earnings, a high share of services in total exports, and high merchandise imports. The merchandise export base is very small in value and diversity of exportable. Export earnings come predominantly from exports of fish and bananas. Non-traditional exports have marginal importance. Traditionally Cape Verde's most substantial export earnings come from non-factor services rendered to international maritime transport, and more recently from international air traffic services. Maritime services are provided through the port of Mindelo, and air services through Sal international airport. The economy is highly dependent on imports of food, capital, and intermediary goods. Emigration is the principal pressure release valve on the Cape Verdean economy. Emigration is also seen as a key means of escape from poverty. At the same time, remnittances of emigrants play an important role in the economy and poverty reduction. The regular flow of remittances is facilitated by confidence in macro-economic management and adequate communication and transport infrastructure. Between 1989 and 1992, remittances averaged nearly 12% of GDP. 2.5 The inward-looking policies of the late 1970s and early 1980s proved unsustainable in terms of good economic performance. Economic growth fell in 1989 to 3.7% and declined further in 1990-92 due to: (a) declines in public investment as a result of completion of some major projects and postponement or cancellation of new ones; (b) decrease in demand for international maritime and air services; (c) poor agricultural outputs as a result of prolonged drought; and (d) deteriorating performance of the public enterprise sector. In 1993, economic growth began to recover thanks to higher public investment in economic and social infrastructure and some private sector investment, particularly foreign, in light manufacturing and fisheries. Preliminary figures indicate a growth of about 4.5%. 2.6 To address economic and financial imbalances, the post-independence government adopted in 1988 an outward-oriented strategy intended to privatize public enterprises and to liberalize trade. Prices of domestic and imported consumer goods have been almost fully liberalized. A large-scale liberalization of the trade system, which started in late 1991 and was successfully broadened in 1992 and 1993, has led to a dynamic growth of imports after many
 3 years of tight controls. To preserve the living standards of the general population, the Government is keeping under import monopoly some essential commodities that are also available in the form of food aid. Although the retail prices of these products reflect the actual CIF import cost and handling charges, they do not reflect fuly transport and distribution costs to remote islands. The GOCV is exploring options to liberalizing the prices of these items. In addition, the foreign exchange allocation system has been streamlined. Foreign exchange is presently aDocated through the existing commercial banks for all imports, currently covering about 97% of all customs items. The authorities are considering lifting the remaining restrictions on payments and transfers for current international transactions. The lack of a natural or mineral resource base, combined with surplus labor, dictates a service-oriented, labor-intensive development strategy. New legislation governing foreign investment, liberalization of domestic and foreign trade and prices, and privatization, aims to channel the economy towards activities such as export- processing zones, tourism, offshore banking services, and intermediate labor-intensive industries, as well as air and maritime services. The government, through multi and bilateral development assistance, is redefining its role as a provider of modern and efficient services in infrastructure such as ports, warehouses, and telecommunications. B. THE PRIVATE SECITOR 1. The Business Environment 2.7 Cape Verde is meagerly endowed with natural resources. However, prospects for private sector development are promising, given Cape Verde's special advantages: political stability, a physical environment attractive for tourism, a largely unexploited reserve of seafood products, a disciplined and relatively well educated labor force and a preferential access to markets in the European Union, the USA and the countries of the Economic Community of the West African States (ECOWAS). The formal private sector plays a dominant role in import and domestic trade, but its contribution is low in manufacturing, tourism and services. The Government has expressed its intention to make the private sector the driving force of the economy. Legislation has already been enacted to attract foreign enterprises and provide incentives to exports (Annex 2). Although some major constraints to this development are already being addressed through Bank Group projects (paras. 2.48-2.49), much remains to be done to develop the private sector. For instance, a number of private enterprises which have been created in recent years by local entrepreneurs, targeting both domestic and external markets, are facing difficulties in obtaining bank financing and have to cope with burdensome administrative procedures resulting in significant delays. 2.8 A large and growing informal private sector is active in most areas of economic activity. However, as many informal sector entrepreneurs are engaged in multiple part-time activities, it is difficult to determine with accuracy the size of the sector. A 1992 study of the artisanal sector by the ELO estimated that about 23,000 persons were engaed in artisanal activities. According to official statistics, 30 to 40% of the active population is employed by microenterprises. The main areas of activities are: (a) retail trade, based mainly on imports from the continent (Senegal and the Gambia); (b) processing of agricultural and seafood products; (c) fisheries; (d) local
 4 production of construction materials; (e) classic artisanal activities such as woodworking, shoe- making, hairdressing; and (f) small restaurants and bars. 2.9 The manufacturing sector's contribution to the economy has gradually increased from 3.7% of GDP in 1980, to 6.8% in 1985, and 8% in 1990. As of 1994, a total of 101 industrial enterprises employed 3,300 persons and were categorized as industrial. Of these, 90% were privately-owned, and 10% were joint ventures between the Government and private investors. Most industrial enterprises are small: only 17% employ more than 50 workers. The private sector plays a dominant role in trade which accounts for 20% of GDP and represents one of the most developed sectors in Cape Verde. This is a legacy from the colonial era when almost everything consumed in the islands was imported from Portugal by traders. 2.10 Cape Verde's climatic conditions, abundance of beautiful beaches, political stability, and proximity by air to major European capitals are important assets for the promotion of tourism. Despite its potential, tourism does not play a significant role in the economy and accounts for only about 2% of GDP. In 1988, the GOCV decided to give priority to tourism development, essentially through the private sector. It is estimated that about 1,300 persons are employed in the sector. The occupancy rates of hotels in Sal and Praia range from 60 to 80%. 2.11 Fisheries, which currently account for less than 3% of GDP, represent another sector in which Cape Verde has a natural comparative advantage due to the high-value of fish species in the surrounding waters. Artisanal fishing in Cape Verde is predominant, accounting for about 85% of all of the fishing activities in the country. About 6% of the sector's total annual catch is processed into canned fish products and fish meal. Detailed information on the various sectors is presented in Annex 3. 2. Institutions providing support to the Private Sector 2.12 Local Institutions. Institutional arrangements reflect the unbalanced role of the public and private sector. In an effort to support private sector development, the Government has created two institutions, PROMEX and IADE, and the private sector has been organized in a nascent form. (Detailed information on these institutions is presented in Annex 4 and summarized below). There are also two trade associations: the Associacao Comercial e Agricola de Sotavento, which includes commercial enterprises located in the islands of Santiago, Fogo, Brava and Maio; and the AssociaVao Comercial, Industrial e Agricola de Barlavento, which includes commercial enterprises in the islands of Sao Vicente, Santo Antao, Sao Nicolau, Sal and Boavista. In effect, these represent the two main competing centers of economic activity, Santiago and Sao Vicente. 2.13 To provide greater support to the private sector, two chambers of commerce (federated at the national level) have been created by grouping professional associations in all sectors of the economy (trade, manufacturing, construction, civil engineering, transport and fisheries). The two chambers are responsible for developing a public/private partnership and maintaining a dialogue with the GOCV regarding the development of the private sector. They are expected to absorb, at an appropriate time, some of the services currently provided by government agencies. The
 5 chambers will also be responsible for organizing an annual forum for private enterprises to further the dialogue between the Government and the private sector. 2.14 PROMEX was created in 1990 by the Government, with assistance from the US Agency for International Development (USAID), to assist in export promotion and foreign investment development. Although withdrawing from Cape Verde at the end of 1995, USAID has committed to funding part of PROMEX's operating expenses up to mid-1996. In 1992, the Government revised PROMEX's statutes to give the agency sufficient autonomy to enable it to fulfill its functions effectively, and PROMEX commenced operations as a one-stop-shop for foreign investors. Since then, it has played a significant role in the preparation of various laws necessary to facilitate the establishment of foreign investments in Cape Verde and in attracting foreign investment to the country. From 1992 to early 1995, PROMEX has attracted five foreign enterprises which have invested US$8.5 million in light manufacturing. This has resulted in creating 800 jobs. In October 1995, PROMEX absorbed a similar institution (INATUR) that had been created in 1993 to promote the tourism sector. 2.15 IADE was created at the beginning of 1992 with the assistance of the African Development Bank for the purpose of developing entrepreneurial capabilities and improving the utilization of the installed productive capacity. LADE, which started operating in October 1993, is expected mainly to provide assistance to small- and medium-size enterprises in technical, financial, commercial, or organizational areas to improve their productivity and their ability to compete in domestic and external markets. Until now, IADE has helped very few enterprises. This is due, in part, to its operating procedures which are complex and cumbersome. 3. Sector issues and constraints 2.16 Despite measures taken by the Government to improve the operating conditions of the private sector, several constraints remain: 2.17 Legal and Regulatory Constraints. One of the predominant constraints concerns the procedures for creating and registering a new enterprise. The current legal procedures are complex, onerous and time-consuming. Registration involves six separate steps and six separate approvals. It takes a minimum of 55 days and requires the payment of approximately 1.7/o of the enterprise's capital in registration fees and stamp taxes. These procedures are being reviewed within the framework of the Public Sector Reform and Capacity Building Project (Cr. 2566-CV) (para. 2.49), and a new simplified system is expected to be implemented by December 1996. 2.18 Financing. Enterprises find it difficult to obtain support from the banking system to finance their investments, even when the projects are sound and the documentation well prepared. Even more disturbing is the length of time it takes a bank to reach credit decisions on corporate requests. By the time a request is finally approved, the parameters upon which the proposed investment were based may have changed significantly. The commercial banking system is not equipped for this type of risk financing, and there are no venture capital nor equity participation facilities in the country. These issues are being addressed under the proposed project by building a capacity in the existing financial institutions (through staff and management training) to make
 6 them more responsive to the needs of the private sector. Other needed financial vehicles, such as venture capital and stock transfer mechanisms (para. 2.36), are being developed by other donors (Sweden) in close coordination with IDA. 2.19 Enterprise Taxation. The fiscal charges levied on enterprises are: 35% tax on profits; 1% tax on transactions, including salaries of employees; five per thousand sales tax paid to the courts on new contracts; 15% tax on salaries for social security; and 3% or 6% tax for workers compensation, depending on whether the employee works in an office or at an open air site. In addition, shareholders pay a flat rate of 15% on dividends, if distributed. This system is complex to administer and burdensome on enterprises. To address this issue, the National Assembly has already approved a law simplifying the corporate tax structure and creating a single corporate tax rate replacing the cascade of rates applied to businesses. A decree specifying the modalities of the implementation of the law, including the tax rates to be applied, has been issued by the Government. The simplified tax system has just begun to be implemented and is addressing this issue. 2.20 The Judicial System. At present, business litigation is handled by the civil court system with all other types of litigation. This has created a significant judicial backlog resulting in delays of one to two years in the adjudication of business disputes, leading to uncertainties in the conduct of business operations. To address this issue and streamline the flow of commercial and industrial litigation, the ongoing Public Sector Reform and Capacity Building Project is helping to strengthen the court system by providing judges with specialized training in commercial litigation. 2.21 Inter-Island and Long Distance Transportation. Transportation of persons and goods between the islands is presently unreliable, erratic and expensive. This also represents a handicap for the development of the inter-island tourism industry and the prospective activities of potential investors. The development of an efficient and reliable inter-island transport system is therefore an important prerequisite for the growth of the private sector. The GOCV has commissioned a study to a private consulting firm, NEA Transport Research and Training, on the inter-island transportation problems and a diagnostic of ARCA VERDE, the public maritime transportation company. The study, financed by the Government, will be completed by July 1996 and will make recommendations to address this issue. The GOCV has already decided to disengage ARCA VERDE from long-distance transportation, leaving this line of business to private companies. ARCA VERDE has sold two of the five long-distance ships it owns and is aggressively seeking buyers for the remaining fleet. This would allow ARCA VERDE to concentrate on inter-island transportation, while private operators would cover export-import transportation. 2.22 Technical Skills. While the level of general education is fairly high, there is an acute shortage of technical skills in areas important for enterprise operations, such as accounting, marketing and personnel management. There is a shortage of skilled staff in hotel operations. However, a technical school was built in late 1995 with European Union funds and is now operational. The school has started training professionals in civil engineering, construction, masonry, accounting and data processing. This is expected to go a long way towards solving the shortage of technical skills.
 7 4. Government Strategy for Private Sector Development 2.23 Government Strategy. The Government is pursuing the implementation of a strategy that aims at: (a) promoting a strong export-oriented manufacturing sector and developing the tourism and fisheries sectors; and (b) taking specific actions to remove obstacles that are impeding the growth of domestic private enterprises. The Government's strategy is detailed in a draft Letter of Private Sector Development Policy (Annex 1). During negotiations. the Government signed the Letter of Private Sector Development Policy, thereby meeting the only condition of Board Presentation of the credit. 2.24 The first element of the strategy includes the following: . In manufacturing, the Government intends to attract foreign enterprises to establish operations in Cape Verde to take advantage of its relatively low labor costs (one-third of those prevailing in Europe) and favorable access to the markets for products such as garments and shoes. To implement the Government's export-led development strategy, PROMEX, in coordination with the municipality of Mindelo on the island of Sao Vicente, has been developing an export-processing zone (EPZ) to provide a location with adequate facilities (water, electricity, roads) where foreign firms interested in Cape Verde can establish their factories. PROMEX's investment goals for 1995-97 are to attract US$19.0 million in new investments that will create 1,200 new jobs and produce US$44.0 million in export revenues. At present, two footwear enterprises from Portugal and a seafood-canning factory are operational. In addition a garment factory is being built. A study carried out by Plant Location International, a subsidiary of Price Waterhouse, stressed that to be successful in its efforts to attract foreign firms, Cape Verde must offer investors adequate infrastructure and factory space. With the initiation of an active search for investors in Portugal and Asia, PROMEX concluded that a critical factor affecting the decision of firms to locate in Cape Verde is the availability of standard factory buildings. * In tourism, the Government's objective is to implement its fifteen-year National Development Plan for Tourism, 1994-2009 (Piano Nacional de Desenvolvimento do Turismo, PNDT) which was prepared by the National Institute for Tourism, (INATUR). The objectives for the 1994-99 period are to: (a) have 62,000 visitors each year by 1999; (b) have 4,500 hotel rooms of international standard, (9,100 beds); (c) increase the average length of stay of tourists from 5.9 to 8 days; (d) create 11,000 new jobs in the hotel sector; (e) generate foreign exchange earnings amounting to USSI 1.0 million during the last year of the plan; (f) promote domestic and foreign investments in the sector; and (g) increase inter-island tourism. Thirteen new hotel projects, which would add about 1,500 beds to the country's lodging capacity, have been identified by private foreign investors with assistance from INATUR. Of these, five have already been approved or are under construction. * In fisheries, the objective is to develop the fishing fleet to take advantage of the ample marine resources which, until now, have not been adequately exploited (para. 2.11).
 8 2.25 The second element of the Government's strategy focuses on facilitating the development of domestic enterprises by improving the business environment in the following areas: * Legal and administrative environment. The Government is taking actions geared to establishing a legal and administrative environment that is favorable to the operations of private enterprises. This includes: revised procedures for creating and registering new enterprises (para. 2.17); significant improvements in customs operations which have speeded up the clearance of imported goods from two weeks to less than two days; the creation, in progress, of a separate commercial jurisdiction within each of the regional courts in order to streamline the flow of commercial and industrial litigations (para. 2.20); and strengthening the banking sector (para. 2.18). * Institutional support to private enterprises. Two chambers of commerce, one for each group of islands (Sotavento and Barlavento), have been created to represent private enterprises' interests in trade, manufacturing, construction, civil engineering, transport and fisheries (para. 2.13). * Building private/public partnership. The chambers will be responsible for organizing, at least twice a year, a forum for private enterprises to further the dialogue between the Government and the private sector. The project will provide support for the organization of such forums. These forums will give the opportunity to government agencies dealing with private sector development and private enterprises to meet and discuss issues concerning the private sector. The resolutions or recommendations made will be incorporated into Governnent policies affecting the sector. * Infrastructure. The Government is taking action to remove bottlenecks in the transport (para. 2.21) and public utility sectors that are impeding the operations and development of private enterprises. Some of the bottlenecks in the public utility sector (high costs of energy and water, unavailability of good water, lack of autonomy of the energy company) are being addressed either in the on-going restructuring of Electra, or in a proposed Energy/Water project expected to be presented to the Board of Directors in September 1997. * Training. Through the creation of a training fund, financed under the Bank Basic Education and Training Project (Cr. 2675-CV), the Government is providing resources for improving the technical skills of workers. 2.26 The strategy being implemented is appropriate and, if pursued with determination, should begin to produce beneficial results shortly. In addition to creating employment, foreign enterprises settling in Cape Verde will likely heighten the level of technological expertise in the country and will contribute to the training of workers. It is also expected that, as the export sector grows, additional needs for production and service activities will be generated, resulting in further development of domestic enterprises.
 9 2.27 Recent Performance and Policies. To translate into action its commitment to let the private sector play a leading role in the country's economic development, the Government has enacted the following measures: the law on Foreign Investments (lei 89/IV/93 of December 13, 1993), the law on Incentives to Exports (lei 92/1V/93 of December 15, 1993), and the law on Export-Processing Zones (lei 991IV/93 of December 31, 1993). Information about these laws is presented in Annex 2. C. THE FINANCIAL SECTOR 1. Overview 2.28 Cape Verde's financial system consists of the Banco de Cabo Verde (BCV), the central bank; the Banco Comercial do Atlantico (BCA), and the Caixa Economica de Cabo Verde (CECV), the former postal savings bank. There are also two insurance companies: the state- owned Companhia de Seguros Garantia (Garantia) and the privately-owned Companhia Caboverdiana de Seguros Impar (Impar). The social security services of the former Inslituto de Seguros e Previdencia Social (ISPS) were reorganized in 1991 under the Instituto Nacional de Previdencia Social (INPS), or Previdencia, within the administrative jurisdiction of the MEC. A small rural credit fund, Caixa de Credito Rural (CCR), has recently been established by the MEC. As of December 31, 1994, combined gross assets of the financial sector, including the BCV, totalled approximately CVE 49 billion (US$664 million). When excluding BCV and insurance companies, BCA's assets represent 900/e of the commercial banldng sector. The Government aims to reduce BCA's market share to no more than 50%/0 within the next three years through Caixa Economica's rapid growth (averaging 30% a year), the entry of foreign banks, and downsizing of BCA (Annex 1). 2.29 The financial sector is poorly developed and suffers from serious macroeconomic constraints, including a small domestic market, and an inefficient public sector, heavily dependent on treasury financing. Additionally, there are persistent fiscal imbalances, absence of a secure and reliable payment system, and lack of an effective regulatory and investment framework to stimulate sector and national development. Substantial efforts are currently being devoted to revising the legal infrastructure with support from the World Bank under the Public Sector Reform and Capacity Building Project (Cr. 2566-CV). The country enjoys a relatively stable monetary system which should provide a good basis for the satisfactory operation and gradual expansion of a market-oriented financial sector. 2. Institutional Structure of the Financial Sector 2.30 The Banco de Cabo Verde (BCV) is responsible for conducting monetary policy, supervising banks and mnanaging foreign exchange reserves. It falls within the administrative purview of the Minister of Economic Coordination. BCV used also to be the country's only commercial bank, but under the structural reform progran agreed upon with the World Bank and the IMF, the commercial activities of the BCV were transferred in 1993 to a new institution, Banco Comercial do Atlantico. Technical advice to support this process was financed under the project preparation facility of the proposed Capacity Building Project for Private Sector
 10 Promotion. The only commercial banking function remaining at the BCV is a small recovery unit responsible for collecting residual delinquent private sector commercial loans which were not transferred to the Banco Comercial do Atlantico. Although BCV has occasionally exceeded the legal limit on government deficit financing (10% of previous year's revenues), its overall approach to government credit has traditionally been conservative. 2.31 The Banco Comercia do Adantico (BCA) was established by the Government in September 1993 to assume BCV's former commercial activities, and is the dominant commercial bank, holding 900/% of all deposits. The bank's financial condition quickly deteriorated as a result of the large amount of problem loans that were transferred to the new bank and of disequilibrium in the asset and liability mix. As a result, BCA's initial authorized capital of CVE 500 million (US$6.6 million) was rapidly depleted. BENEFTS AND JUSTIFICATION 5.1 The proposed project would assist the Government in its efforts to promote private sector development and modernize the financial system. By supporting PROMEX and the EPZ, the project would help develop dynamic export and tourism sectors which are essential elements of the Government's economic development strategy. The main benefits are expected to arise from job creation in an economy where unemployment is the main problem. Enterprises attracted to the EPZ would create employment and contribute to poverty alleviation. Similarly, hotel investments by foreigners would facilitate the growth of tourism, also creating employment and contributing to foreign exchange earnings. An efficient financial sector would contribute to the implementation of an effective monetary and credit policy and to the stability and growth of the Cape Verdean economy. The strengthening of the financial institutions would promote competition and increase their efficiency which in turn would improve access to capital, enhance domestic resource mobilization, and significantly lower the transaction costs of enterprises. A well-functioning financial sector would facilitate the development of the private sector and the privatization of public enterprises. The investment in training and expert advice would improve local capacity in the financial and private sectors. The Social Security Fund, the Instituto Nacional de Preudencia Social, represents an invaluable reservoir of long-term financial resources. Accordingly, restoration of its financial health should facilitate the channeling of these resources to support economic growth..
 33 B. EMLOYmNT AND POVERTY ALLEVATION 5.2 Twenty-three percent of the working-age population of Cape Verde is officially classified as "unemployed". The project would contribute to the alleviation of this problem by directly creating about 2,700 jobs in the Mindelo's EPZ over a four-year period. It is estimated that a similar number of jobs would be created indirectly. The total employment impact in the manufacturing sector would therefore be about 5,500 new jobs. Furthermore, investments in the tourism sector and the development of tourism activities should result in the creation of about 750 directly-generated and some 400 indirectly-generated new jobs. Therefore, the total employment impact of the project would amount to some 6,600 new jobs (equivalent to 6% of the country's economically active population). Through the creation of employment both in the manufacturing and in the tourism sectors, the project would make a significant contribution to the alleviation of poverty. C. These weaknesses are as follows: Classification of Assets, Provisioning, and Treatment of Interest on Non-Performing Assets. An existing regulation classifies loans and requires minimum provisions based only on historic performnance, i.e., past due status. Since one reason for grading the quality of credit is to identify problems at an early stage when they can still be corrected, the classification criteria should focus not only on historic performance but also, and very importantly, on prospective performance. An assessment should be made of a borrower's ability to repay the bank through primary sources of repayment, i.e., cash flow for term debt, and the business asset conversion cycle for working capital credit. This assessment can only be made through current and satisfactory financial information obtained from the borrower through the life of a loan. The current regulation serves to understate the problems existing within the loan portfolio since many problem assets will not immediately show up as past due. In addition, provisioning rates are liberal when compared to past due status. For instance, a loan up to three months past due requires only a 1% provision. By the time a loan is approaching three months past due, it is likely that all liquid assets have already been dissipated. Thus, the risk of loss must be higher than only 1%. Further, specific rules should be established

The regulation should also require write-off of old outstanding items and classification of other assets such as foreclosed real estate. Capital Adequacy. There is an existing regulation requiring a minimum capital adequacy ratio using a risk-weighted assets formula. However, the risk-weights assigned to certain asset categories are questionable given the economic environment in which the banks are operating. Of these, the weight of 50% assigned to housing loans is the most questionable. Although the Basle guideline allows national discretion and permits a 50% weight for residential mortgage loans, the weighting was the subject of much dispute within the Committee. In Cape Verde, since real estate is the most widely used collateral, the 50% weight tends to dilute the mandatory minimum capital requirement. Collateral, in most cases, does not repay loans. If the bank had to foreclose, there would be the expense and time of foreclosure, costs to maintain or improve the property before it could be sold, the costs of security guards, opportunity costs as funds are tied up in a non-earning asset which, most likely, is being funded by an interest-bearing liability, etc. Thus, real estate is not the panacea to sound assessment of a borrower's primary sources of repayment. Many countries have experienced collapses in their residential property markets. Further, the legal system in Cape Verde does not yet permit timely foreclosure or repossession of collateral. There are strong arguments, therefore, for saying that loans secured by real estate are a normal banking risk--a risk which should require a standard risk-weight of 100%. Uncovered Foreign Exchange Positions. A regulation should establish the outside constraints on risk-taking by banks in foreign exchange activities. These constraints should limit the net open position in any single currency and the aggregate net open position in all currencies, as a percent of the bank's unimpaired capital and reserves. In addition, the regulation should require that all positions in foreign currency are revalued at least monthly and all losses, realized or unrealized, resulting from the revaluation are immediately recognized as an expense of the bank and all gains, realized or unrealized, resulting from the revaluation are immediately recognized as income to the bank. The regulation should also require banks to formulate written policies governing foreign exchange activities. These policies should include a formal ratification of internal limits, within the tolerances established by the regulation, governing overnight open positions by currency and for all currencies combined. Where the volume of activities warrants, intraday limits should also be established. Limits should also be established for counterparty credit, settlement, and country risks. Country limits should be established for total exposures to all counterparties in each country. Limits should also be established for foreign currency interest rate and liquidity risks as part of overall asset and liability management. Resolution of Failed Banks. The Banco de Cabo Verde should have powers to close an institution when it is technically insolvent or approaching technical insolvency, i.e., the value of the bank's assets is less than the amount of its liabilities. When a bank is permitted to operate while insolvent, its losses are most likely to grow rapidly in a perverse, but unsustainable, spiral of interest rate increases on deposits and ratcheting up of the amount of bad loans in the portfolio -- culminating in the eventual illiquidity of the bank and potential govermnent liability to depositors. The resolution of failed banks is a difficult and complex issue in all countries. It is important, then, that the Banco de Cabo Verde is granted a broad array of discretionary powers to deal with such situations. The experience of most countries suggests that ad-hoc approaches do not work when attempting to resolve failed bank situations. If a failed bank is to be restructured, certain key principles apply: a) the bank's management is removed; b) the shareholders, who have lost their investment, are wiped out by the losses sustained; c) the bad assets are carved out of the balance sheet, preferably with government bonds; and d) the pricing of the bonds used in

The legal framework should permit the central bank to undertake all these actions, i.e., to declare a bank insolvent and closed, to remove management, to wipe out the shareholders of a failed bank, and to carve out bad assets, in a timely manner based on the factual conditions existing. When a political decision is involved, action often is delayed, causing losses to mount. In a liquidation situation, in order to maintain the stability of the banking system and avoid a banking panic, the Banco de Cabo Verde may find it necessary to finance the payoff of depositors or assumption of deposits by another institution. The usual rule in deciding whether to restructure or liquidate and the methodology to be used is that the least cost alternative should be used, provided that stability in the banking system is maintained. Given the complexity of these issues, particularly during times of financial system distress, the legal framework should be strengthened to provide for such possibilities in advance of the actual need. It is true that a conventional approach that includ investors' capital and profits, and calculated overall value-addd modified by the shadow- price of labor would yield very much lower NPVs and rates of return, but in fact it can fairly easily be shown that these would simply be the sum, in the case of the NPV, and the weighted average in the case of the ERR of the high rate of return for Cape-Verde Inc. and the lower rate of return that the investors would be assumed (without any real evidence) to earn on their capital. An example of this is given above in the sensitivity analysis in the manurin industry component. The fact that this averaged result is lower deflects critical scrutiny, but does not make it any more accurate. Indeed, it is probably less accurate. Moreover, it yields a result that is a far less useful as a criterion of how Cape-Verde should use the resources it controls, or as an indicator of the rewards to success in this enterprise. 22. In fact, these high returns are a fair indicator of the rwards a poor, low-income country can reap by successfully attracting foreign investment. The critical fictor is the probability or plausibility of success. The cost-benefit of expending a worm to catch a large fish is very high, but the ex-ante calculation is of little value unless the probability of success is taken into account. In general, the less plausible (and hence the lower the cost) of a government's efforts to attract a given quantity of overseas investmt, the higher will be the apparet ex-ante rate of return. What matters far more is the coherence and plausibility of the promotion activities in question. At the same time, a rather important conclusion is that even a promotion campaign that might be seen as rather unsuccessful (as represented by the lower limits of the sensitivity analyses) can produce very attractive nationally-owned returns - attractive enough to justify very considerable additional expenditures if initial results fall short of expectations.

doc.abstracts: The capacity Building Project for Private Sector Promotion's long term development objectives are: 1) employment creation in the formal sector; and 2) a well functioning financial sector. The specific implementation objectives are: 1) for the private sector, to enhance the country's foreign exchange earnings, attract foreign investments and improve the performance of private enterprises; and 2) for the financial sector, to enhance the functioning of the Central Bank of Cape Verde (BCV) as a monetary authority and improve financial intermediation through strengthening of banks and non-banking institutions. The project will comprise the following components: 1) a private sector component which consists of: (a) institutional support to the Export and Investment Promotion Center including: (i) development of export manufacturing activities; (ii) development of tourism activities; (iii) development of an export processing zone in Mindelo; (iv) establishment of an international marine registry; (v) establishment of a video-conferencing facility; and (vi) private sector coordination services; and (b) support to domestic enterprises; and 2) a financial sector component consisting of: (a) assistance to BCV; (b) institutional strengthening of Banco Comercial do Atlantico; (c) support to Caixa Economica de Cabo Verde; (d) support to the Instituto de Seguros de Cabo Verde; and (e) support to the Instituto Nacional de Previdencia Social. The second component of the project will also include some advisory services, equipment, training, technical support, external audit, privatization plan and management information system and computer equipment.
